evidence_span: In the case of doublesided oxidation at 1200 and $1 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ , the outer diameter of Zircaloy-4 tubing expanded by up to $12 \%$ , and the inner diameter by up to $8 \%$ . The corresponding gain in wall thickness was about $30 \%$ to $60 \%$ .

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: Unpublished results from tests on Zircaloy in 1-atm steam at Chalk River contradict some of your results. Our results on oxidation kinetics in the two-phase $( \alpha + \beta )$ temperature range do show a breakaway transition to near linear kinetics.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: The use of standard creep rate correlations and a burst criterion based on local true stress to evaluate Zircaloy cladding ballooning and burst strain is discussed.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: Burst strains calculated by this means are shown to follow the trends observed in tubing burst tests.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: Calculation of the ballooning strains for the Three Mile Island-2 fuel rods, ignoring the effects of oxidation, are discussed.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: This work has included both basic creep and tension testing, and transient and creep rupture biaxial ballooning tests.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: This work has included both basic creep and tension testing, and transient and creep rupture biaxial ballooning tests.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: This work has included both basic creep and tension testing, and transient and creep rupture biaxial ballooning tests.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: Most LOCA ballooning and burst models have been based on empirical correlations of burst test results using heatup rate, burst temperature, and engineering burst stress as parameters.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: Erbacher [1], Chung and Kassner [2], and others have observed that burst strains are closely related to circumferential temperature gradients in the bursting region of the test specimen.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_053_chunk4
evidence_span: Burman and Kuchirka [3] and Chung and Kassner [2] showed, at least for tests in which heatup rate was controlled by varying power input while maintaining constant external heating, that circumferential temperature differences are directly proportional to heatup rate.
